elements.content: We first designed and synthesized a new semirigid tripodal ligand with tetrazole groups, 1,3,5-tri­(4-(2H-tetrazol-5-yl)­phenoxy)­benzene (H 3 TTPB). Two isostructural microporous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), namely [Cu3(TTPB)2­(H2O)6]·5DMF (JUC-130) and [Cd3(TTPB)2­(H2O)6]·6DMF (JUC-131) (JUC = Jilin University, China), were successfully synthesized under solvothermal reactions based on this ligand, which both possess two-dimensional (2D) frameworks based on similar trinuclear metal centers as secondary building units (SBUs). H 3 TTPB was designed as the organic building block, not only because it is suitable to construct functionalized microporous frameworks with numerous nitrogen atoms but also by reason for its blue luminescent emission. Gas sorption measurements indicated that they are both microporous frameworks. JUC-130 showed high stability in water and selective sorption capabilities for alcohol and water vapors, which may be further used for the separation of alcohol–water mixtures. In addition, JUC-131 exhibited interesting and important fluorescent properties, which can be used as one of the few known MOFs useful for the detection of nitroaromatics via “supramolecular wire effect”.
elements.clean_text: We first designed and synthesized a new semirigid tripodal ligand with tetrazole groups, 1,3,5-tri(4-(2H-tetrazol-5-yl)phenoxy)benzene (H  3  TTPB). Two isostructural microporous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), namely [Cu3(TTPB)2(H2O)6]⋅5DMF (JUC-130) and [Cd3(TTPB)2(H2O)6]⋅6DMF (JUC-131) (JUC = Jilin University, China), were successfully synthesized under solvothermal reactions based on this ligand, which both possess two-dimensional (2D) frameworks based on similar trinuclear metal centers as secondary building units (SBUs). H  3  TTPB was designed as the organic building block, not only because it is suitable to construct functionalized microporous frameworks with numerous nitrogen atoms but also by reason for its blue luminescent emission. Gas sorption measurements indicated that they are both microporous frameworks. JUC-130 showed high stability in water and selective sorption capabilities for alcohol and water vapors, which may be further used for the separation of alcohol-water mixtures. In addition, JUC-131 exhibited interesting and important fluorescent properties, which can be used as one of the few known MOFs useful for the detection of nitroaromatics via "supramolecular wire effect".

elements.content: Two isostructural microporous metal−organic frameworks based on a tritopic semirigid ligand with tetrazole groups were successfully synthesized under solvothermal reactions, which exhibited various applications in sorption properties and nitroaromatic explosives sensing.
elements.clean_text: Two isostructural microporous metal-organic frameworks based on a tritopic semirigid ligand with tetrazole groups were successfully synthesized under solvothermal reactions, which exhibited various applications in sorption properties and nitroaromatic explosives sensing.

elements.content: Owe to their richness architectures and great potential applications, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), as a new class of organic–inorganic hybrid porous coordination polymers, have received great interest in the past two decades. These materials can be applied potentially in the fields of gas storage, separation, luminescence, catalysis and drug delivery etc. MOFs are built from metal ions/clusters as nodes and organic bridging ligands as linkers, which both play vital roles to tune the structural topology and functionality. Among enormous variety of ligands, flexible tritopic ligands are widely used because of intriguing varieties of molecular architectures and potential functional applications, such as 1,3,5-tri­(4-carboxyphenoxy)­benzene and 2,4,6-tri­(4-carboxyphenoxy)-1,3,5-triazine. MOFs, constructed by such ligands, can generate novel structures with many attractive sorption and luminescence properties. Recently, tetrazolate and their derivatives as five-membered N-heterocyclic azoles also have received extensive attention not only because of the richness of properties, but also for their excellent stabilities. However, as we know, no previous investigations have been reported to explore the synthesis of MOFs based on tritopic semirigid ligand with tetrazole groups. Evidently, it is a quite interesting and big challenge to generate MOFs with such ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Owe to their richness architectures and great potential applications, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), as a new class of organic-inorganic hybrid porous coordination polymers, have received great interest in the past two decades. These materials can be applied potentially in the fields of gas storage, separation, luminescence, catalysis and drug delivery etc. MOFs are built from metal ions/clusters as nodes and organic bridging ligands as linkers, which both play vital roles to tune the structural topology and functionality. Among enormous variety of ligands, flexible tritopic ligands are widely used because of intriguing varieties of molecular architectures and potential functional applications, such as 1,3,5-tri(4-carboxyphenoxy)benzene and 2,4,6-tri(4-carboxyphenoxy)-1,3,5-triazine. MOFs, constructed by such ligands, can generate novel structures with many attractive sorption and luminescence properties. Recently, tetrazolate and their derivatives as five-membered N-heterocyclic azoles also have received extensive attention not only because of the richness of properties, but also for their excellent stabilities. However, as we know, no previous investigations have been reported to explore the synthesis of MOFs based on tritopic semirigid ligand with tetrazole groups. Evidently, it is a quite interesting and big challenge to generate MOFs with such ligands.

elements.content: On the other hand, the properties of MOFs can also be tuned by metal ions, such as Ln3+, Cu2+, Al3+, Zn2+, Cd2+ and so on. As far as we known, d10 transition-metal ions have generally been investigated for luminescent materials based on flexible tritopic ligands. The permanent porosity of MOFs also plays a central role in guest species recognition and response. Sujit K. Ghosh et al. first reported a highly luminescent two-dimensional (2D) MOF containing continuous π-stack cylindrical arrays in a backbone for fast and reversible solid-state detection of aromatic nitro explosives via a fluorescence quenching mechanism, namely “supramolecular wire effect”. In our previous study, we have developed tunable colors and white-light luminescence materials by the encapsulation of Ln3+ species in a microporous blue luminescent MOF JUC-113. Considering the thoughts above, it is of great significance to design and synthesize a new semirigid tripodal ligand with tetrazole groups to construct microporous MOFs with multifunctions.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, the properties of MOFs can also be tuned by metal ions, such as Ln3+, Cu2+, Al3+, Zn2+, Cd2+ and so on. As far as we known, d10 transition-metal ions have generally been investigated for luminescent materials based on flexible tritopic ligands. The permanent porosity of MOFs also plays a central role in guest species recognition and response. Sujit K. Ghosh et al. first reported a highly luminescent two-dimensional (2D) MOF containing continuous π-stack cylindrical arrays in a backbone for fast and reversible solid-state detection of aromatic nitro explosives via a fluorescence quenching mechanism, namely "supramolecular wire effect". In our previous study, we have developed tunable colors and white-light luminescence materials by the encapsulation of Ln3+ species in a microporous blue luminescent MOF JUC-113. Considering the thoughts above, it is of great significance to design and synthesize a new semirigid tripodal ligand with tetrazole groups to construct microporous MOFs with multifunctions.

elements.content: In this work, we first designed and synthesized a new semirigid tripodal ligand with tetrazole groups, 1,3,5-tri­(4-(2H-tetrazol-5-yl)­phenoxy)­benzene (H 3 TTPB, Scheme ). It was designed as the organic building block, not only because it is suitable to construct functionalized microporous frameworks with numerous nitrogen atoms, which would improve the selectivity in the separation of alcohol–water mixtures, but also the flexibility may provide intraligand interaction by aromatic π–π stacking to generate highly luminescent character. Under solvothermal reactions with CuCl2·2H2O and Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O, H 3 TTPB was combined with Cu­(II) and Cd­(II) to form two isostructural 2D MOFs, namely [Cu3(TTPB)2­(H2O)6]·5DMF (JUC-130) and [Cd3(TTPB)2­(H2O)6]·6DMF (JUC-131) (JUC = Jilin University, China). MOFs, constructed from different transit metals, would realize different applications. Gas measurements showed that they are both microporous frameworks. In addition, JUC-130 exhibited excellent water stability and selective sorption capabilities for alcohol and water vapors. On the other hand, JUC-131 displayed an interesting and important fluorescent property to detect nitroaromatic explosives.
elements.clean_text: In this work, we first designed and synthesized a new semirigid tripodal ligand with tetrazole groups, 1,3,5-tri(4-(2H-tetrazol-5-yl)phenoxy)benzene (H  3  TTPB, Scheme ). It was designed as the organic building block, not only because it is suitable to construct functionalized microporous frameworks with numerous nitrogen atoms, which would improve the selectivity in the separation of alcohol-water mixtures, but also the flexibility may provide intraligand interaction by aromatic π-π stacking to generate highly luminescent character. Under solvothermal reactions with CuCl2⋅2H2O and Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O, H  3  TTPB was combined with Cu(II) and Cd(II) to form two isostructural 2D MOFs, namely [Cu3(TTPB)2(H2O)6]⋅5DMF (JUC-130) and [Cd3(TTPB)2(H2O)6]⋅6DMF (JUC-131) (JUC = Jilin University, China). MOFs, constructed from different transit metals, would realize different applications. Gas measurements showed that they are both microporous frameworks. In addition, JUC-130 exhibited excellent water stability and selective sorption capabilities for alcohol and water vapors. On the other hand, JUC-131 displayed an interesting and important fluorescent property to detect nitroaromatic explosives.

elements.clean_text: 1  Structure of Ligand H  3  TTPB

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray crystallography reveals that JUC-130 and JUC-131 are isostructural with different metals. Here, JUC-130 is selected to discuss the structure in detail. The structure of JUC-130 exhibits a 2D coordination framework with double-(6, 3)-layers in the trigonal R3̅ space group. In the asymmetric unit, there is one-sixth Cu1 ion, one-third Cu2 ion, one-third TTPB3– ligand, and one terminal H2O (). As shown in Figure a, the crystallographically independent two Cu­(II) centers (Cu1 and Cu2) are linked by tetrazolyl rings in the sequence Cu2–Cu1–Cu2 to form a trinuclear unit. Cu1 is octahedrally coordinated by six nitrogen atoms from different ligands (Cu1–N, 2.131–2.133 Å). Cu2 is also six-coordinated by three nitrogen atoms from different ligands (Cu2–N, 2.057–2.059 Å) and three oxygen atom from different terminal H2O (Cu2–O, 1.907–1.909 Å). Meanwhile, the Cd–N and Cd–O distances in JUC-131 are 2.325–2.379, 2.327–2.329 Å respectively. The trinuclear metal unit in JUC-130 can also be seen as two triangular paddle-wheel units connected by the central Cu1. Triangular paddle-wheel units have been reported in many structures, which are very stable and easy to form 2D frameworks. As shown in Figure b, each trinuclear unit is connected by six TTPB3– to form a double-(6,3)-layer. The double-(6,3)-layer can be regarded so that each triangular paddle-wheel unit connects three ligands to form one (6,3)-layer, and two layers are connected by Cu1 atoms to form a double-(6,3)-layer. The two layers in one bilayer were stack in AB fashion, where each benzene ring is situated to cover the hexagonal pore of the other layer. If the trinuclear centers and the TTPB3– ligands were simplified as 6-connected and 3-connected nodes respectively, the simplified network (Figure f) belongs to a (6,3)-connected kgd topology with the Schläfli symbol of (43)2(46·66·83). The double-layers are packed together in ABC fashion by aromatic π–π stacking (3.827 Å) to form a 3D supermolecular architecture (Figure c–e). The layer-packing framework has 1D open rhombic channels of approximately 6 × 8 Å2 (measured distance between opposite atoms) along the c-axis (Figure d). After elimination of guest molecules and coordinated water molecules, the total accessible volume in JUC-130 is 57.0% using the PLATON/VOID routine.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure Description

Single crystal X-ray crystallography reveals that JUC-130 and JUC-131 are isostructural with different metals. Here, JUC-130 is selected to discuss the structure in detail. The structure of JUC-130 exhibits a 2D coordination framework with double-(6, 3)-layers in the trigonal R3̅ space group. In the asymmetric unit, there is one-sixth Cu1 ion, one-third Cu2 ion, one-third TTPB3- ligand, and one terminal H2O (). As shown in Figure a, the crystallographically independent two Cu(II) centers (Cu1 and Cu2) are linked by tetrazolyl rings in the sequence Cu2-Cu1-Cu2 to form a trinuclear unit. Cu1 is octahedrally coordinated by six nitrogen atoms from different ligands (Cu1-N, 2.131-2.133 Å). Cu2 is also six-coordinated by three nitrogen atoms from different ligands (Cu2-N, 2.057-2.059 Å) and three oxygen atom from different terminal H2O (Cu2-O, 1.907-1.909 Å). Meanwhile, the Cd-N and Cd-O distances in JUC-131 are 2.325-2.379, 2.327-2.329 Å respectively. The trinuclear metal unit in JUC-130 can also be seen as two triangular paddle-wheel units connected by the central Cu1. Triangular paddle-wheel units have been reported in many structures, which are very stable and easy to form 2D frameworks. As shown in Figure b, each trinuclear unit is connected by six TTPB3- to form a double-(6,3)-layer. The double-(6,3)-layer can be regarded so that each triangular paddle-wheel unit connects three ligands to form one (6,3)-layer, and two layers are connected by Cu1 atoms to form a double-(6,3)-layer. The two layers in one bilayer were stack in AB fashion, where each benzene ring is situated to cover the hexagonal pore of the other layer. If the trinuclear centers and the TTPB3- ligands were simplified as 6-connected and 3-connected nodes respectively, the simplified network (Figure f) belongs to a (6,3)-connected kgd topology with the Schläfli symbol of (43)2(46⋅66⋅83). The double-layers are packed together in ABC fashion by aromatic π-π stacking (3.827 Å) to form a 3D supermolecular architecture (Figure c-e). The layer-packing framework has 1D open rhombic channels of approximately 6 × 8 Å2 (measured distance between opposite atoms) along the c-axis (Figure d). After elimination of guest molecules and coordinated water molecules, the total accessible volume in JUC-130 is 57.0% using the PLATON/VOID routine.

elements.content: (a) Coordination environments of Cu (II) atoms (symmetry code: #3: y – 1/3, −x + y + 1/3, −z + 1/3; #4: x – y + 2/3, x + 1/3, −z + 1/3; #5: −x + 2/3, −y + 4/3, −z + 1/3; #6: −x + y, −x + 1, z; #7: −y + 1, x – y + 1, z). (b) View of the single 2D network along the c-axis. (c) The 2D networks of JUC-130 are packed together in ABC fashion to form a 3D supramolecular architecture along the c-axis. (d) The π–π stacking between the layers. (e) View of the packed layers along the a-axis. (The hydrogen atoms and solvent molecules are omitted for clarity.) (f) The simplified network of the single 2D network along the c-axis.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination environments of Cu (II) atoms (symmetry code: #3: y - 1/3, -x + y + 1/3, -z + 1/3; #4: x - y + 2/3, x + 1/3, -z + 1/3; #5: -x + 2/3, -y + 4/3, -z + 1/3; #6: -x + y, -x + 1, z; #7: -y + 1, x - y + 1, z). (b) View of the single 2D network along the c-axis. (c) The 2D networks of JUC-130 are packed together in ABC fashion to form a 3D supramolecular architecture along the c-axis. (d) The π-π stacking between the layers. (e) View of the packed layers along the a-axis. (The hydrogen atoms and solvent molecules are omitted for clarity.) (f) The simplified network of the single 2D network along the c-axis.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) of JUC-130 and JUC-131 confirmed the phase purity of their bulk crystalline materials. As shown in Figure a, the peaks on the PXRD patterns of as-synthesized samples of JUC-130 and JUC-131 are coincident with those on their respective simulated patterns. From the thermogravimetric analyses (Figure b), JUC-130 showed a slow weight loss of 25.11% before 190 °C, which corresponds to the loss of guest H2O and terminal DMF molecules (calculated 26.27%). The framework then collapsed and decomposed with the increase of temperature. The residue was CuO (experimental: 11.33% and calculated: 13.52%). For JUC-131, it is found that there was a weight loss of 28.17% before 200 °C, which could be attributable to the loss of guest DMF and terminal H2O molecules (calculated 26.77%). The residue was CdO (experimental: 16.47% and calculated: 18.87%). The as-synthesized samples were activated via soaking in methanol and CH2Cl2 and then evacuated to obtain their activated samples. The PXRD patterns of the activated samples are shown in , which showed the activated frameworks were almost containing their structures.
elements.clean_text:
Stability and Porosity

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) of JUC-130 and JUC-131 confirmed the phase purity of their bulk crystalline materials. As shown in Figure a, the peaks on the PXRD patterns of as-synthesized samples of JUC-130 and JUC-131 are coincident with those on their respective simulated patterns. From the thermogravimetric analyses (Figure b), JUC-130 showed a slow weight loss of 25.11% before 190 °C, which corresponds to the loss of guest H2O and terminal DMF molecules (calculated 26.27%). The framework then collapsed and decomposed with the increase of temperature. The residue was CuO (experimental: 11.33% and calculated: 13.52%). For JUC-131, it is found that there was a weight loss of 28.17% before 200 °C, which could be attributable to the loss of guest DMF and terminal H2O molecules (calculated 26.77%). The residue was CdO (experimental: 16.47% and calculated: 18.87%). The as-synthesized samples were activated via soaking in methanol and CH2Cl2 and then evacuated to obtain their activated samples. The PXRD patterns of the activated samples are shown in , which showed the activated frameworks were almost containing their structures.

elements.content: (a) Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of JUC-130 and JUC-131. (b) TGA curves of JUC-130 (red) and JUC-131 (black).
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of JUC-130 and JUC-131. (b) TGA curves of JUC-130 (red) and JUC-131 (black).

elements.content: In order to verify their permanent porosities, gas sorption isotherms of activated JUC-130 and JUC-131 were measured. Both JUC-130 and JUC-131 did not uptake N2 gas at 77 K. However, as shown in Figure , the CO2 adsorption isotherms at 195 K revealed that they are typical microporous materials, which reach the value of 129 cm3 g–1 (25 wt %) and 107 cm3 g–1 (21 wt %) at 1 bar for JUC-130 and JUC-131. The CO2 adsorption was increased to 60 cm3 g–1 (12 wt %) and 68 cm3 g–1 (13 wt %) by a sharp gas uptake at a low-pressure region (P/P 0 < 0.1) and the uptake increased as the pressure increased, which is typically observed for micoporous materials. The observed hysteresis in the CO2 isotherms was similar to the literature examples, which may be attributed to the small pore windows and pore expansion in MOFs. The Langmuir surface areas of JUC-130 and JUC-131 are 423 and 372 m2 g–1, respectively. The results may be due to the molecular sieve effect (kinetic diameter: CO2, 3.30 Å; N2, 3.64 Å) of the small channels. Meanwhile, the quadrupole moment of CO2 also may facilitate the penetration of gas molecules into the pores, which can be attributed to the enhanced interactions between CO2 and numerous nitrogen atoms of the framework.
elements.clean_text:
Gas and Vapor Sorption

In order to verify their permanent porosities, gas sorption isotherms of activated JUC-130 and JUC-131 were measured. Both JUC-130 and JUC-131 did not uptake N2 gas at 77 K. However, as shown in Figure , the CO2 adsorption isotherms at 195 K revealed that they are typical microporous materials, which reach the value of 129 cm3 g-1 (25 wt %) and 107 cm3 g-1 (21 wt %) at 1 bar for JUC-130 and JUC-131. The CO2 adsorption was increased to 60 cm3 g-1 (12 wt %) and 68 cm3 g-1 (13 wt %) by a sharp gas uptake at a low-pressure region (P/P 0 < 0.1) and the uptake increased as the pressure increased, which is typically observed for micoporous materials. The observed hysteresis in the CO2 isotherms was similar to the literature examples, which may be attributed to the small pore windows and pore expansion in MOFs. The Langmuir surface areas of JUC-130 and JUC-131 are 423 and 372 m2 g-1, respectively. The results may be due to the molecular sieve effect (kinetic diameter: CO2, 3.30 Å; N2, 3.64 Å) of the small channels. Meanwhile, the quadrupole moment of CO2 also may facilitate the penetration of gas molecules into the pores, which can be attributed to the enhanced interactions between CO2 and numerous nitrogen atoms of the framework.

elements.content: Sorption isotherms of JUC-130 (a) and JUC-131 (b): CO2 (blue: 195 K) and N2 (red: 77 K, solid symbols: adsorption and open symbols: desorption).
elements.clean_text: 3  Sorption isotherms of JUC-130 (a) and JUC-131 (b): CO2 (blue: 195 K) and N2 (red: 77 K, solid symbols: adsorption and open symbols: desorption).

elements.content: JUC-130 exhibits high stability in water (). However, the framework of JUC-131 was more easily destroyed in water. The reason may be that the longer bond lengths of Cd–N (2.327–2.377 Å) than Cu–N (2.058–2.132 Å) are responsible for weaker bond strengths. On the other hand, the coordination geometry around the d10 Cd­(II) might tend to be more readily distorted by the addition of water molecules, leading to the framework destruction. In contrast, the d9 Cu­(II) would be stabilized due to the ligand field stabilization energy and the Jahn–Teller distortion, which are not related to the d10 Cd­(II). The porosity and high stability of JUC-130 allow potential applications in the separation of alcohol–water mixtures. Vapor adsorption studies for H2O, MeOH, and EtOH were carried out on activated JUC-130 at 298 K. As shown in Figure , JUC-130 exhibits hysteretic adsorption behavior to H2O, MeOH, and EtOH, not only because it has easily accessible hydrogen-bond interaction sites from the N atoms but also by reason for the unsaturated Cu2+ sites to generate the strong adsorbate–adsorbent interaction. It also takes up significantly different saturated amounts of MeOH, H2O, and EtOH of 144, 97, and 41 cc g–1, respectively. The different sorption capabilities in this case are probably due to the combination of size-selectively adsorbing and different adsorbate–adsorbent interactions. The saturated amounts of EtOH are much less than in the case of MeOH and H2O, probably because ethanol molecules had a larger kinetic diameter (4.5 Å) than methanol (3.6 Å) and water molecules (2.68 Å). It is noteworthy that the kinetic diameter of MeOH is larger than that of H2O, but the uptake of MeOH is more than that of H2O. A similar phenomenon was reported for a number of MOFs, which is mainly due to the matching of MeOH molecules into the small pores to enhance the much stronger interactions between the host porous framework and guest methanol molecules.
elements.clean_text: JUC-130 exhibits high stability in water (). However, the framework of JUC-131 was more easily destroyed in water. The reason may be that the longer bond lengths of Cd-N (2.327-2.377 Å) than Cu-N (2.058-2.132 Å) are responsible for weaker bond strengths. On the other hand, the coordination geometry around the d10 Cd(II) might tend to be more readily distorted by the addition of water molecules, leading to the framework destruction. In contrast, the d9 Cu(II) would be stabilized due to the ligand field stabilization energy and the Jahn-Teller distortion, which are not related to the d10 Cd(II). The porosity and high stability of JUC-130 allow potential applications in the separation of alcohol-water mixtures. Vapor adsorption studies for H2O, MeOH, and EtOH were carried out on activated JUC-130 at 298 K. As shown in Figure , JUC-130 exhibits hysteretic adsorption behavior to H2O, MeOH, and EtOH, not only because it has easily accessible hydrogen-bond interaction sites from the N atoms but also by reason for the unsaturated Cu2+ sites to generate the strong adsorbate-adsorbent interaction. It also takes up significantly different saturated amounts of MeOH, H2O, and EtOH of 144, 97, and 41 cc g-1, respectively. The different sorption capabilities in this case are probably due to the combination of size-selectively adsorbing and different adsorbate-adsorbent interactions. The saturated amounts of EtOH are much less than in the case of MeOH and H2O, probably because ethanol molecules had a larger kinetic diameter (4.5 Å) than methanol (3.6 Å) and water molecules (2.68 Å). It is noteworthy that the kinetic diameter of MeOH is larger than that of H2O, but the uptake of MeOH is more than that of H2O. A similar phenomenon was reported for a number of MOFs, which is mainly due to the matching of MeOH molecules into the small pores to enhance the much stronger interactions between the host porous framework and guest methanol molecules.

elements.content: Methanol (green triangles), water (blue squares), and ethanol (red circles) vapor adsorption isotherms of desolvated JUC-130 at 298 K (solid symbols: adsorption and open symbols: desorption).
elements.clean_text: 4  Methanol (green triangles), water (blue squares), and ethanol (red circles) vapor adsorption isotherms of desolvated JUC-130 at 298 K (solid symbols: adsorption and open symbols: desorption).

elements.content: Luminescent coordination complexes with d10 transition-metal clusters have been attracting intensive research interest for luminescent materials, owing to their potential applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, and electroluminescent displays. The solid-state luminescent properties of free H 3 TTPB ligand and JUC-131 were analyzed at room temperature. As shown in Figure a, the free H 3 TTPB ligand exhibits emission at 417 nm upon excitation at 366 nm. Compared to the excitation and emission spectra of the free H 3 TTPB ligand, JUC-131 shows a similar emission at 440 nm in the solid state (λex = 366 nm), which indicates that the luminescent property of JUC-131 is mostly attributed to the emission of the organic linker. The spectral red shift (23 nm) is mainly attributed to the intraligand transition and ligand-to-metal, which are in good agreement with literature examples on this class of d10 transition-metal coordination compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Property and Detection for Nitroaromatic Compounds

Luminescent coordination complexes with d10 transition-metal clusters have been attracting intensive research interest for luminescent materials, owing to their potential applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, and electroluminescent displays. The solid-state luminescent properties of free H  3  TTPB ligand and JUC-131 were analyzed at room temperature. As shown in Figure a, the free H  3  TTPB ligand exhibits emission at 417 nm upon excitation at 366 nm. Compared to the excitation and emission spectra of the free H  3  TTPB ligand, JUC-131 shows a similar emission at 440 nm in the solid state (λex = 366 nm), which indicates that the luminescent property of JUC-131 is mostly attributed to the emission of the organic linker. The spectral red shift (23 nm) is mainly attributed to the intraligand transition and ligand-to-metal, which are in good agreement with literature examples on this class of d10 transition-metal coordination compounds.

elements.content: To investigate the luminescent sensing ability of JUC-131, the emission spectra of JUC-131 crystal powder dispersing in DMF with different analytes of 0.5 M were measured considering that it was insoluble and exhibited high fluorescence intensity in DMF (Figure b). The fluorescence intensity became very weak for 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 1,3-dinitrobenzene (1,3-DNB), and nitrobenzene (NB). These results are similar to those reported by Sujit K. Ghosh et al., which can be used as one of the few known MOFs useful for the detection of high explosives via a fluorescence quenching mechanism, namely the “supramolecular wire effect”. In order to gain insight into the fluorescence quenching process, JUC-131 was titrated with various nitroaromatics in DMF at room temperature. Represented by NB in DMF with different concentrations, the fluorescent intensity clearly decreased with increasing NB amount. Furthermore, the ratio [(I 0/I) – 1] of the fluorescence intensities in the absence and presence of quenchers was approximately linearly increased with increasing the concentration of NB (Figure c). The Stern–Volmer plot of luminescent intensity [(I 0/I) – 1] vs the concentration of NB is shown in Figure c. The Stern–Volmer constant (K SV) was 2.2 × 102 M–1 for NB. The quenching and recovery experiments were carried out to study the stability and recyclability of JUC-131 for the luminescent detection of NB. The JUC-131 powder may be recycled by centrifuging the dispersed solution and washing five times with DMF. As shown in Figure d, the fluorescence intensity and quenching ability of JUC-131 exhibit very little changes after being used for at least seven cycles. The high stability of the recovered sample after seven cycles of quenching and recovery were demonstrated by PXRD patterns ().
elements.clean_text: To investigate the luminescent sensing ability of JUC-131, the emission spectra of JUC-131 crystal powder dispersing in DMF with different analytes of 0.5 M were measured considering that it was insoluble and exhibited high fluorescence intensity in DMF (Figure b). The fluorescence intensity became very weak for 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 1,3-dinitrobenzene (1,3-DNB), and nitrobenzene (NB). These results are similar to those reported by Sujit K. Ghosh et al., which can be used as one of the few known MOFs useful for the detection of high explosives via a fluorescence quenching mechanism, namely the "supramolecular wire effect". In order to gain insight into the fluorescence quenching process, JUC-131 was titrated with various nitroaromatics in DMF at room temperature. Represented by NB in DMF with different concentrations, the fluorescent intensity clearly decreased with increasing NB amount. Furthermore, the ratio [(I 0/I) - 1] of the fluorescence intensities in the absence and presence of quenchers was approximately linearly increased with increasing the concentration of NB (Figure c). The Stern-Volmer plot of luminescent intensity [(I 0/I) - 1] vs the concentration of NB is shown in Figure c. The Stern-Volmer constant (K SV) was 2.2 × 102 M-1 for NB. The quenching and recovery experiments were carried out to study the stability and recyclability of JUC-131 for the luminescent detection of NB. The JUC-131 powder may be recycled by centrifuging the dispersed solution and washing five times with DMF. As shown in Figure d, the fluorescence intensity and quenching ability of JUC-131 exhibit very little changes after being used for at least seven cycles. The high stability of the recovered sample after seven cycles of quenching and recovery were demonstrated by PXRD patterns ().

elements.content: (a) Excitation (dot lines) and emission (solid lines) spectra of free H 3 TTPB ligand (black) and JUC-131 (blue) in the solid. (b) Fluorescence intensity of JUC-131 crystal powder after immersed in DMF with different analytes of 0.5 M at room temperature upon excitation at 366 nm. (c) The emission spectra of JUC-131 titrated in DMF with NB. The insets indicate the Stern–Volmer plot. (d) Reproducibility of JUC-131 dispersed in DMF with NB of 0.5 M. JUC-131 crystal powder of 4.0 mg was dispersed in DMF of 3.0 mL.

(b) Fluorescence intensity of JUC-131 crystal powder after immersed in DMF with different analytes of 0.5 M at room temperature upon excitation at 366 nm. (c) The emission spectra of JUC-131 titrated in DMF with NB. The insets indicate the Stern-Volmer plot. (d) Reproducibility of JUC-131 dispersed in DMF with NB of 0.5 M. JUC-131 crystal powder of 4.0 mg was dispersed in DMF of 3.0 mL.

elements.content: In summary, we successfully synthesized two isostructural microporous MOFs JUC-130 and JUC-131 based on a tritopic semirigid ligand with tetrazole groups. Gas sorption measurements indicated that they are both microporous frameworks. JUC-130 is highly stable in alcohol and water and shows selective sorption capabilities for alcohol and water vapors. In addition, JUC-131 can be used as one of the few known MOFs for the detection of high explosives via supramolecular wire effect. This work opens a promising approach to the design and synthesis of interesting and useful MOF materials based on the tritopic semirigid ligand with tetrazole groups. It is expected that there will be more extensive research to explore and develop such ligands with different metal ions to construct MOFs for various applications. Further work on the assembly of the ligand H 3 TTPB with other metal ions/clusters is still underway in our laboratory along with exploration of other applications.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we successfully synthesized two isostructural microporous MOFs JUC-130 and JUC-131 based on a tritopic semirigid ligand with tetrazole groups. Gas sorption measurements indicated that they are both microporous frameworks. JUC-130 is highly stable in alcohol and water and shows selective sorption capabilities for alcohol and water vapors. In addition, JUC-131 can be used as one of the few known MOFs for the detection of high explosives via supramolecular wire effect. This work opens a promising approach to the design and synthesis of interesting and useful MOF materials based on the tritopic semirigid ligand with tetrazole groups. It is expected that there will be more extensive research to explore and develop such ligands with different metal ions to construct MOFs for various applications. Further work on the assembly of the ligand H  3  TTPB with other metal ions/clusters is still underway in our laboratory along with exploration of other applications.

elements.content: All the chemical reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a PerkinElmer 240 analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were acquired on a Scintag X1 diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ =1.5418 Å) at 50 kV, 200 mA with a 2θ range of 4°–40° at room temperature. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed with a PerkinElmer TGA thermogravimetric analyzer in the range of 30°–800 °C under air flow at a heating rate of 10 °C/min for all measurements. Fourier-transform infrared spectra (FT-IR) were obtained as KBr pellets in the 4000–400 cm–1 range using a Nicolet Impact 410 FT-IR spectrometer. All fluorescence measurements were recorded on a Fluoromax-4 Spectrofluorometer at room temperature. Gas and vapor sorption–desorption measurements and were performed using an Autosorb-iQ2-MP-AG machine. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AV 400 spectrometer with Me4Si as the internal standard in deuterated solvent DMSO-d 6 at 298 K.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All the chemical reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a PerkinElmer 240 analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were acquired on a Scintag X1 diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ =1.5418 Å) at 50 kV, 200 mA with a 2θ range of 4°-40° at room temperature. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed with a PerkinElmer TGA thermogravimetric analyzer in the range of 30°-800 °C under air flow at a heating rate of 10 °C/min for all measurements. Fourier-transform infrared spectra (FT-IR) were obtained as KBr pellets in the 4000-400 cm-1 range using a Nicolet Impact 410 FT-IR spectrometer. All fluorescence measurements were recorded on a Fluoromax-4 Spectrofluorometer at room temperature. Gas and vapor sorption-desorption measurements and were performed using an Autosorb-iQ2-MP-AG machine. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AV 400 spectrometer with Me4Si as the internal standard in deuterated solvent DMSO-d 6 at 298 K.

elements.content: First, 1,3,5-tri­(4-cyano­phenoxy)­benzene was prepared according to the literature procedure. A mixture of 1,3,5-tri­(4-cyano­phenoxy)­benzene (0.43 g, 1 mmol), tetrabutyl­ammonium fluoride (1.18 g, 4.5 mmol), and trimethyl­silyl azide (0.52 g, 4.5 mmol) was stirred for 1 day at 85 °C in a high pressure reaction tube. After cooling to room temperature, 5 mL of ethanol were added to the mixture. It was stirred for 1 h to obtain a clear solution at room temperature. Then the solution was poured into water (100 mL) to yield a white precipitate. The resulting white product was collected and washed with distilled water (3 × 10 mL). The yield was then dried to give 0.51 g (91%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d 6), δ (ppm): 6.58 (s, 3H); 7.27 (d, 6H); 8.03 (d, 6H). Selected FT-IR data (KBr pellet, cm–1): 2964 (s), 2873 (s), 1597 (s), 1500 (s), 1446 (s), 1220 (s), 1172 (s), 1114 (s), 1066 (s), 1001 (s), 840 (s), 754 (s), 669 (s), 518 (s).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 1,3,5-Tri(4-(2H-tetrazol-5-yl)phenoxy)benzene (H  3  TTPB)

First, 1,3,5-tri(4-cyanophenoxy)benzene was prepared according to the literature procedure. A mixture of 1,3,5-tri(4-cyanophenoxy)benzene (0.43 g, 1 mmol), tetrabutylammonium fluoride (1.18 g, 4.5 mmol), and trimethylsilyl azide (0.52 g, 4.5 mmol) was stirred for 1 day at 85 °C in a high pressure reaction tube. After cooling to room temperature, 5 mL of ethanol were added to the mixture. It was stirred for 1 h to obtain a clear solution at room temperature. Then the solution was poured into water (100 mL) to yield a white precipitate. The resulting white product was collected and washed with distilled water (3 × 10 mL). The yield was then dried to give 0.51 g (91%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d 6), δ (ppm): 6.58 (s, 3H); 7.27 (d, 6H); 8.03 (d, 6H). Selected FT-IR data (KBr pellet, cm-1): 2964 (s), 2873 (s), 1597 (s), 1500 (s), 1446 (s), 1220 (s), 1172 (s), 1114 (s), 1066 (s), 1001 (s), 840 (s), 754 (s), 669 (s), 518 (s).

elements.content: A mixture of CuCl2·2H2O (10 mg, 0.059 mmol), H 3 TTPB (10 mg, 0.018 mmol), N,N-dimethyl­formamide (DMF, 6 mL), and isopropanol­amine (25 μL) was sealed into a 20 mL capped vessel. The vessel was heated at 85 °C. Blue crystals were obtained after 3 days and washed with DMF and dried in air. Yield: 73% (based on H 3 TTPB); FT-IR (KBr): 2927 (br), 1652 (s), 1595 (s), 1529 (s), 1438 (s), 1380(s), 1216 (s), 1164 (s), 1112 (s), 756 (s), 665 (s), 509 (s). Anal. Calcd for C69H77O17N29Cu3: C, 46.64; H, 4.34; N, 22.87%. Found: C, 46.83; H, 4.41; N, 22.54%.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Cu3(TTPB)2(H2O)6]⋅5DMF (JUC-130)

A mixture of CuCl2⋅2H2O (10 mg, 0.059 mmol), H  3  TTPB (10 mg, 0.018 mmol), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 6 mL), and isopropanolamine (25 μL) was sealed into a 20 mL capped vessel. The vessel was heated at 85 °C. Blue crystals were obtained after 3 days and washed with DMF and dried in air. Yield: 73% (based on H  3  TTPB); FT-IR (KBr): 2927 (br), 1652 (s), 1595 (s), 1529 (s), 1438 (s), 1380(s), 1216 (s), 1164 (s), 1112 (s), 756 (s), 665 (s), 509 (s). Anal. Calcd for C69H77O17N29Cu3: C, 46.64; H, 4.34; N, 22.87%. Found: C, 46.83; H, 4.41; N, 22.54%.

elements.content: A mixture of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (10 mg, 0.032 mmol), H 3 TTPB (5 mg, 0.009 mmol), DMF (6 mL), and isopropanol­amine (25 μL) was sealed into a 20 mL capped vessel. Then HNO3 (2 M) was added dropwise until the mixture became clear. The mixture after standing at 75 °C for 2 days gave yellow block-shaped crystals. Yield: 78% (based on H 3 TTPB). FT-IR (KBr): 2927 (br), 1653 (s), 1595 (s), 1529 (s), 1437 (s), 1380(s), 1215 (s), 1164 (s), 1113 (s), 756 (s), 664 (s), 509 (s). Anal. Calcd for C72H84O18N30Cd3: C, 42.32; H, 4.11; N, 20.57%. Found: C, 42.26; H, 4.06; N, 20.39%.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Cd3(TTPB)2(H2O)6]⋅6DMF (JUC-131)

A mixture of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (10 mg, 0.032 mmol), H  3  TTPB (5 mg, 0.009 mmol), DMF (6 mL), and isopropanolamine (25 μL) was sealed into a 20 mL capped vessel. Then HNO3 (2 M) was added dropwise until the mixture became clear. The mixture after standing at 75 °C for 2 days gave yellow block-shaped crystals. Yield: 78% (based on H  3  TTPB). FT-IR (KBr): 2927 (br), 1653 (s), 1595 (s), 1529 (s), 1437 (s), 1380(s), 1215 (s), 1164 (s), 1113 (s), 756 (s), 664 (s), 509 (s). Anal. Calcd for C72H84O18N30Cd3: C, 42.32; H, 4.11; N, 20.57%. Found: C, 42.26; H, 4.06; N, 20.39%.

elements.content: Crystallographic data collections for JUC-130 and JUC-131 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD based diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 298 K. Corrections for incident and diffracted beam absorption effects were applied to the date using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by a combination of direct methods and refined by the full matrix least-squares method against F 2 values using the SHELXTL program. All non-hydrogen atoms were located successfully from Fourier maps and were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. Because JUC-130 and JUC-131 contained many disordered solvent molecules, the PLATON/SQUEEZE was applied to remove their diffraction contribution. The guest molecules can be calculated from the TGA and elemental analyses (C, H, and N). Crystallographic data for the structure are reported in , and the selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in .
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal X-ray Crystallography

Crystallographic data collections for JUC-130 and JUC-131 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD based diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 298 K. Corrections for incident and diffracted beam absorption effects were applied to the date using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by a combination of direct methods and refined by the full matrix least-squares method against F 2 values using the SHELXTL program. All non-hydrogen atoms were located successfully from Fourier maps and were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. Because JUC-130 and JUC-131 contained many disordered solvent molecules, the PLATON/SQUEEZE was applied to remove their diffraction contribution. The guest molecules can be calculated from the TGA and elemental analyses (C, H, and N). Crystallographic data for the structure are reported in , and the selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in .

elements.content: Details of experimental results, PXRD, TGA, FT-IR, 1H NMR, crystal structure data, and CIF files. The supplementary crystallographic data for this paper were deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC) as entry CCDC and . This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Details of experimental results, PXRD, TGA, FT-IR, 1H NMR, crystal structure data, and CIF files. The supplementary crystallographic data for this paper were deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC) as entry CCDC  and . This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content:
Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) of JUC-130 and JUC-131 confirmed the phase purity of their bulk crystalline materials. As shown in Figure a, the peaks on the PXRD patterns of as-synthesized samples of JUC-130 and JUC-131 are coincident with those on their respective simulated patterns. From the thermogravimetric analyses (Figure b), JUC-130 showed a slow weight loss of 25.11% before 190 °C, which corresponds to the loss of guest H2O and terminal DMF molecules (calculated 26.27%). The framework then collapsed and decomposed with the increase of temperature. The residue was CuO (experimental: 11.33% and calculated: 13.52%). For JUC-131, it is found that there was a weight loss of 28.17% before 200 °C, which could be attributable to the loss of guest DMF and terminal H2O molecules (calculated 26.77%). The residue was CdO (experimental: 16.47% and calculated: 18.87%). The as-synthesized samples were activated via soaking in methanol and CH2Cl2 and then evacuated to obtain their activated samples. The PXRD patterns of the activated samples are shown in , which showed the activated frameworks were almost containing their structures.

Gas and Vapor Sorption

In order to verify their permanent porosities, gas sorption isotherms of activated JUC-130 and JUC-131 were measured. Both JUC-130 and JUC-131 did not uptake N2 gas at 77 K. However, as shown in Figure , the CO2 adsorption isotherms at 195 K revealed that they are typical microporous materials, which reach the value of 129 cm3 g–1 (25 wt %) and 107 cm3 g–1 (21 wt %) at 1 bar for JUC-130 and JUC-131. The CO2 adsorption was increased to 60 cm3 g–1 (12 wt %) and 68 cm3 g–1 (13 wt %) by a sharp gas uptake at a low-pressure region (P/P 0 < 0.1) and the uptake increased as the pressure increased, which is typically observed for micoporous materials. The observed hysteresis in the CO2 isotherms was similar to the literature examples, which may be attributed to the small pore windows and pore expansion in MOFs. The Langmuir surface areas of JUC-130 and JUC-131 are 423 and 372 m2 g–1, respectively. The results may be due to the molecular sieve effect (kinetic diameter: CO2, 3.30 Å; N2, 3.64 Å) of the small channels. Meanwhile, the quadrupole moment of CO2 also may facilitate the penetration of gas molecules into the pores, which can be attributed to the enhanced interactions between CO2 and numerous nitrogen atoms of the framework.

Luminescent Property and Detection for Nitroaromatic Compounds

Luminescent coordination complexes with d10 transition-metal clusters have been attracting intensive research interest for luminescent materials, owing to their potential applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, and electroluminescent displays. The solid-state luminescent properties of free H 3 TTPB ligand and JUC-131 were analyzed at room temperature. As shown in Figure a, the free H 3 TTPB ligand exhibits emission at 417 nm upon excitation at 366 nm. Compared to the excitation and emission spectra of the free H 3 TTPB ligand, JUC-131 shows a similar emission at 440 nm in the solid state (λex = 366 nm), which indicates that the luminescent property of JUC-131 is mostly attributed to the emission of the organic linker. The spectral red shift (23 nm) is mainly attributed to the intraligand transition and ligand-to-metal, which are in good agreement with literature examples on this class of d10 transition-metal coordination compounds.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Stability and Porosity

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) of JUC-130 and JUC-131 confirmed the phase purity of their bulk crystalline materials. As shown in Figure a, the peaks on the PXRD patterns of as-synthesized samples of JUC-130 and JUC-131 are coincident with those on their respective simulated patterns. From the thermogravimetric analyses (Figure b), JUC-130 showed a slow weight loss of 25.11% before 190 °C, which corresponds to the loss of guest H2O and terminal DMF molecules (calculated 26.27%). The framework then collapsed and decomposed with the increase of temperature. The residue was CuO (experimental: 11.33% and calculated: 13.52%). For JUC-131, it is found that there was a weight loss of 28.17% before 200 °C, which could be attributable to the loss of guest DMF and terminal H2O molecules (calculated 26.77%). The residue was CdO (experimental: 16.47% and calculated: 18.87%). The as-synthesized samples were activated via soaking in methanol and CH2Cl2 and then evacuated to obtain their activated samples. The PXRD patterns of the activated samples are shown in , which showed the activated frameworks were almost containing their structures.

Gas and Vapor Sorption

In order to verify their permanent porosities, gas sorption isotherms of activated JUC-130 and JUC-131 were measured. Both JUC-130 and JUC-131 did not uptake N2 gas at 77 K. However, as shown in Figure , the CO2 adsorption isotherms at 195 K revealed that they are typical microporous materials, which reach the value of 129 cm3 g-1 (25 wt %) and 107 cm3 g-1 (21 wt %) at 1 bar for JUC-130 and JUC-131. The CO2 adsorption was increased to 60 cm3 g-1 (12 wt %) and 68 cm3 g-1 (13 wt %) by a sharp gas uptake at a low-pressure region (P/P 0 < 0.1) and the uptake increased as the pressure increased, which is typically observed for micoporous materials. The observed hysteresis in the CO2 isotherms was similar to the literature examples, which may be attributed to the small pore windows and pore expansion in MOFs. The Langmuir surface areas of JUC-130 and JUC-131 are 423 and 372 m2 g-1, respectively. The results may be due to the molecular sieve effect (kinetic diameter: CO2, 3.30 Å; N2, 3.64 Å) of the small channels. Meanwhile, the quadrupole moment of CO2 also may facilitate the penetration of gas molecules into the pores, which can be attributed to the enhanced interactions between CO2 and numerous nitrogen atoms of the framework. 

Luminescent Property and Detection for Nitroaromatic Compounds

Luminescent coordination complexes with d10 transition-metal clusters have been attracting intensive research interest for luminescent materials, owing to their potential applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, and electroluminescent displays. The solid-state luminescent properties of free H  3  TTPB ligand and JUC-131 were analyzed at room temperature. As shown in Figure a, the free H  3  TTPB ligand exhibits emission at 417 nm upon excitation at 366 nm. Compared to the excitation and emission spectra of the free H  3  TTPB ligand, JUC-131 shows a similar emission at 440 nm in the solid state (λex = 366 nm), which indicates that the luminescent property of JUC-131 is mostly attributed to the emission of the organic linker. The spectral red shift (23 nm) is mainly attributed to the intraligand transition and ligand-to-metal, which are in good agreement with literature examples on this class of d10 transition-metal coordination compounds.

<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">

<title>Structure of Ligand <bold>H</bold>

</caption>
<graphic id="gr1" orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="cg-2015-00229g_0003.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

(a) Coordination environments of Cu (II) atoms (symmetry code: #3: y – 1/3, −x + y + 1/3, −z + 1/3; #4: x – y + 2/3, x + 1/3, −z + 1/3; #5: −x + 2/3, −y + 4/3, −z + 1/3; #6: −x + y, −x + 1, z; #7: −y + 1, x – y + 1, z). (b) View of the single 2D network along the c-axis. (c) The 2D networks of JUC-130 are packed together in ABC fashion to form a 3D supramolecular architecture along the c-axis. (d) The π–π stacking between the layers. (e) View of the packed layers along the a-axis. (The hydrogen atoms and solvent molecules are omitted for clarity.) (f) The simplified network of the single 2D network along the c-axis.

metadata.title:
Sorption Properties and Nitroaromatic Explosives Sensing
Based on Two Isostructural Metal–Organic Frameworks
